metadata.title: Rwanda-Backed Rebels Killed over 140 Civilians in Eastern Congo, Rights Group Says

left: The M23 armed group, backed by the Rwandan government, attacked villages in July, committing dozens of summary executions of primarily Hutu civilians, reported Clémentine de Montjoye from Human Rights Watch.
Human Rights Watch has identified 141 people who were killed or are missing, feared dead, due to these attacks.
The killings seem to be part of a military campaign against the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda, a Hutu armed group linked to the 1994 genocide.
De Montjoye stated that the M23’s actions highlight the disparity between international rhetoric and the dire conditions for civilians in eastern Congo.
center: Human Rights Watch said M23 rebels killed at least 140 civilians, mostly Hutus, in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo in July.
Witnesses said the Rwanda-backed rebels used machetes and gunfire to attack people in at least 14 villages near Virunga National Park between July 10 and 30.
The report cited accounts from witnesses, medical workers, military and UN personnel that members of the Rwanda Defence Force backed the M23 operation.
right: M23 rebels killed at least 140 people in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo in July, according to Human Rights Watch.
Total killings in Rutshuru territory may exceed 300, supporting previous findings by the United Nations.
A woman described witnessing M23 kill her husband during the attacks.
Human Rights Watch called for expanded sanctions and urged access for U.N. experts into M23-controlled areas.
